Process

Design is centered around the creative process. I have adapted my previous knowledge to fit a new process of design in software engineering.

Inventory & Analysis

The first step is always to identify the problem, and take inventory of what is already known. Learn what the client wants, needs or dreams of to improve their business. Take account of what the client already has, or identify similarities to previous projects.

Conceptual Design

Lay out a quick "sketch" of the project at a high level. The pseudo-code. Identify areas that need clarification, as well as the team's strengths and weaknesses in order to proceed with efficiency.

Master Planning

Take a modular approach to the concept - break down the design into small pieces to work methodically through the project. Coordinate each step with the team to ensure all elements are built and implemented seamlessly.

About

fruor itineris

  • May 2013

    Delaware Valley University

    Graduated with a BS in environmental design. I learned and studied the design process. My education background taught me how to break down all situations into step-by-step solutions using this process of identifying the issues and working incrementally tackle each one.

  • November 2015

    Landscape Design-Build

    I spent over four years working as a designer for a small landscape design-build company in a very fast-paced environment. I was constantly challenged to assess, develop and improve my organizational skills, as well as my project and time management abilities by working on multiple projects simultaneously with ever-changing scope and deadlines.

  • 2019 - 2020

    Transition

    Around this time, I started to feel the path that I was currently on was not the right path for me. I made the difficult decision to leave my career in pursuit of a new challenge. This gave me an opportunity to dive into the world of coding and development, and brought me to General Assembly. I decided to pursue the Software Engineering Immersive Program to accelerate my learning and seek success.

  • August 2014

    Software Engineering Immersive Fellowship

    The immersive course at General Assembly provided the foundation of knowledge to develop and improve my skills as a software engineer. The 500+ hour fellowship included three individual projects and one team project, focusing on not only learning the fundamentals of languages like JavaScript and Python, but the tools to enhance our own learning process, like how to efficiently learn outside the classroom and on the job. The experience included fundamentals of software engineering such as Github and Command Line, as well as JavaScript, Node.js, and frameworks like Express and React; even a second language in Python. Most importantly, I gained the confidence to fail, learn, and overcome the issues I will inevitably face in coding, and the feeling of excitement in tackling these once-impossible challenges with the resources I developed and will continue to improve as part of a team and organization.

  • Seeking
    the next
    Opportunity!

Resume
Built by Kyle Bini with Start Bootstrap

Back in 10!

Calendar app focused on wellness

Back in 10! is a full stack planning application that emphasises wellness and personal and mental health. The application allows a user to create calendar style events centered around taking breaks for wellness activities. With many individuals working remotely, it is important to create a routine that provides a balance of work and personal activities. Taking breaks or even a few minutes at a time have been shown to improve mental health, relieve stress, and actually increase productivity at work. By adding events to a formal schedule, it blocks out time during the day that a user is unavailable (say, if this were synced with an employee's meeting schedule), and provides "rigidity" for those that are more inclined to maintain a structured schedule. Future versions will include a calendar component (eg. the react-big-calendar), a dropdown menu of activities with the option to input custom events, and a random activity generator.

  • Primary Tools: React.js, Express.js
  • Deployed Site
  • Client Repository

PlusOne

Social event application

PlusOne is an application that allows users to post events they are hosting or attending, and invite others or allow other users to RSVP that they are also attending. The idea behind the app was to allow someone with an extra ticket to an event to create a post, and allow another user to join or RSVP to that post. Unauthorized users are able to see all events, but must sign up or sign in to view specific details and RSVP. This project was completed with a team of three other developers, with the objective of learning to manage multiple branches and code conflicts, as well as learning to work in a team environment.

  • Primary Tools: React.js, Express.js
  • Deployed Site
  • Client Repository

Take a Hike!

Hike tracking application

Take a Hike! is a full stack application for logging hikes or exercise activities. It is basically a primitive version of the MapMyRun or AllTrails apps. The user is able to create a log entry including the location, distance hiked and difficulty rating. This project was an exercise in performing CRUD actions, and learning the connections between the client side requests and server side responses. This was our first full stack application, built using an Express API template to handle our requests. This application was constructed with the requirements of having a User and at least one relationship (Hikes). Future versions will include comments, sorting by difficulty and hike locations with multiple hike entries.

  • Primary Tools: JavaScript, Express.js, Handlebars
  • Deployed Site
  • Client Repository

Tic-Tac-Toe

Frontend game application

This was our first project at General Assembly; an exercise in creating a frontend application using an existing API. The task was to create a tic-tac-toe game in which a user can play a game (against a human opponent or themselves) to get three-in-a-row. Users should be able to play alternating game pieces, and should not be allowed to play on a box that has been taken, or play after a game has already been won.

  • Primary Tools: HTML, CSS, JavaScript
  • Deployed Site
  • Client Repository
  • You will be asked to log in or sign up;
    please do not use a real email address, there is no encryption/hashing.

Map My Move

(A working title) Inventory app focused on organization to assist with moving

This is my next upcoming project, an application designed to act as an inventory management system for homeowners (or even moving companies) to assist in tracking your "stuff" during and after moving. This is inspired by my wife and I having moved six times in the last five years; many of our items have barely made it out of the box before being packed away again, and some of our items are being stored at our respective parents' houses while we search for yet another location to move. It is a struggle and a hassle to label everything in a box, and even tougher to remember where that specific box or item is in a stack of boxes at multiple locations. This application will be a way to organize information in a table to better keep track of your items while you are in transition.

  • Planning to Use: React.js, Python/Django
  • Deployed Site TBD
  • Client Repository TBD
